page.title: Don't Let Us Sing Anymore About War, Just Let Us Sing of Love (Peace Song)

revision.comment: clean up / fix section header naming ([[WP:ASL]]), added [[CAT:O|orphan]] tag using [[Project:AWB|AWB]] (12068)
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=August 2016}}
{{Infobox song <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Songs --> | Name =Don't Let Us Sing Anymore About War, Just Let Us Sing of Love (Peace Song) | cover = Don't let us sing anymorea bout war, just let us sing of love.jpg | caption = Sheet music cover at the [[Pritzker Military Museum & Library]] | English_title = | Type = | Artist = [[Harry Lauder]] | original_artist = | alt Artist = | recorded_by = | performed_by = | Album = | A-side = | Recorded = {{Start date|1918|12|10}} | Released = 1918 | Published = | Genre = [[Pop music|Pop]] | Length = {{Duration|m=03|s=51}} | Writer = Harry Lauder | Language = English | Form = | Label = T.B. Harms Music Co.; [[Victor Talking Machine Company|Victor Records]] | Producer = | ISWC = | Tracks = | prev = | prev_no = | track_no = | next = | next_no = | Misc = }} '''"Don't Let Us Sing Anymore About War, Just Let Us Sing of Love (Peace Song)"''' is a [[World War I]] era song released in 1918. Lyrics and music were written by [[Harry Lauder]].<ref>Vogel (1995) p. 167 ''World War I Songs: A History and Dictionary of Popular American Patriotic Tunes, with Over 300 Complete Lyrics'' (McFarland & Company, Inc.)</ref> It was published by T.B. Harms and Francis, Day & Hunter, Music Co. of [[New York, New York]]. The sheet music cover features a photo of Lauder with his autograph.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Parker |first1=Bernard S. |date=2007 |volume=1 |title=World War I Sheet Music |location=Jefferson |publisher=McFarland & Company, Inc. |page=113 |isbn=978-0-7864-2798-7}}</ref> The song was written for both voice and piano.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://jscholarship.library.jhu.edu/handle/1774.2/14228 |title=Don't Let Us Sing Anymore About War, Just Let Us Sing Us Love. Peace Song. |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |website=JScholarship |publisher=JScholarship |access-date=3 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://repository.library.brown.edu/studio/item/bdr:94934/ |title=Don't let us sing anymore about war, just let us sing of love |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |website=Brown University Library |publisher=Brown University |access-date=3 March 2016}}</ref>
On December 10, 1918, Lauder recorded the song with conductor [[Josef Pasternack]]. It was released by [[Victor Talking Machine Company|Victor Records]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.loc.gov/jukebox/recordings/detail/id/4630/ |title=Don't let us sing anymore about war, just let us sing of love |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |website=Library of Congress National Jukebox |publisher=Library of Congress |access-date=3 March 2016}}</ref>
The lyrics are a celebration of the end of war. The chorus, the proclamations of excited soldiers, is as follows:<ref>Vogel (1995) p. 308 ''World War I Songs: A History and Dictionary of Popular American Patriotic Tunes, with Over 300 Complete Lyrics'' (McFarland & Company, Inc.)</ref> :''"Hurray, the war is over!'' :''Hurray, the fight is won!'' :''Back from the life of a rover,'' :''Back from the roar of the gun.'' :''Back to the dear old homeland,'' :''Home with the peaceful dove;'' :''Don't let us sing anymore about war,'' :''Just let us sing of love."''
The sheet music can be found at [[Pritzker Military Museum & Library]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/dont-let-us-sing-anymore-about-war-just-let-us-sing-of-love-peace-song/oclc/13465970 |title=Don't let us sing anymore about war, just let us sing of love : "peace song" |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |website=OCLC WorldCat |publisher=OCLC WorldCat |access-date=3 March 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
